comment: I wonder if these two have played before. I don't recall any games. Ponomariov is still relatively new to the GM tournaments.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6
comment: It's amazing how Najdorf's experiment has held up over the years.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4
comment: This, however, wasn't played back in Najdorf's day.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3
comment: Black has conceded some king-side weakness to kick White's dark-square bishop to a poor square. If White can play f2-f3 he can return Bg3-f2 to control d4, but in the mean time Black is making her own threats (in the spirit of the Dragon Variation) .

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. h3 Nf6 11. Qe2
1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. h3 Nf6 11. Qe2 Nc6 12. Nxc6 bxc6 13. e5 dxe5 14. Bxe5
comment: White is in good control of the diagonal, but can't O-O-O. Black has plenty of open lines for development.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. h3 Nf6 11. Qe2 Nc6 12. Nxc6 bxc6 13. e5 dxe5 14. Bxe5 O-O 15. h4 g4 16. g3 Qb6 17. O-O-O Be6 18. Bg2 Rfd8 19. Rhe1 h5 20. b3
comment: This blunts Be6, but also tells Black how to proceed (...c6-c4xb3) .

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. h3 Nf6 11. Qe2 Nc6 12. Nxc6 bxc6 13. e5 dxe5 14. Bxe5 O-O 15. h4 g4 16. g3 Qb6 17. O-O-O Be6 18. Bg2 Rfd8 19. Rhe1 h5 20. b3 Rac8 21. Na4 Rxd1+ 22. Rxd1 Qb5
comment: It's a curious thing for Black to offer a queen trade as I was just suggesting White should do the same. But, Black wants the trade only on her terms: otherwise White can play Be5-d4 to secure square c5

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. h3 Nf6 11. Qe2 Nc6 12. Nxc6 bxc6 13. e5 dxe5 14. Bxe5 O-O 15. h4 g4 16. g3 Qb6 17. O-O-O Be6 18. Bg2 Rfd8 19. Rhe1 h5 20. b3 Rac8 21. Na4 Rxd1+ 22. Rxd1 Qb5 23. Bf1 Bc4
comment: Wow! This is something special. If bxc4 then ...Qxa4 and Kc1 is weakened. If Qxc4 then ...Qxe5 and at last Bg7 can come into play.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be3 Ng4 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bh4 g5 9. Bg3 Bg7 10. h3 Nf6 11. Qe2 Nc6 12. Nxc6 bxc6 13. e5 dxe5 14. Bxe5 O-O 15. h4 g4 16. g3 Qb6 17. O-O-O Be6 18. Bg2 Rfd8 19. Rhe1 h5 20. b3 Rac8 21. Na4 Rxd1+ 22. Rxd1 Qb5 23. Bf1 Bc4 24. Qxc4 Qxe5
comment: Black may be threatening ...Qa1+ to force White's king out into the open!

Qxe7 Rd2+ 33. Kb1 Qd5 34. Ka1 Ne4 35. Qe8+ Kg7 36. Nb2 Rxb2 37. Kxb2 Qd2+ 38. Ka3 Nf6
comment: winning a piece and the game! That was a pretty neat accurate forceful attack and defense. It shows how careful one has to be with their king to avoid problems.
